htmlEmbed:
COVID-19 outbreak forces metro school to close until next weekFOX 4 Kansas City WDAF-TV | News, Weather, Sports8/28/2025

Leaders at Holy Name of Jesus Catholic School in Kansas City, Kansas, confirmed that classes are canceled until Tuesday due to a COVID-19 outbreak at the school.

COVID, education, Family, health, Homepage, kansas city, Kansas City News, kansas news, KCK, outbreakRead

Leaders at Holy Name of Jesus Catholic School in Kansas City, Kansas, confirmed that classes are canceled until Tuesday due to a COVID-19 outbreak at the school. The school said on social media that classes are expected to resume after the Labor Day break. The post doesn't specify whether students, faculty \u2013 or both \u2013 are affected by this spread. School closures were common during the pandemic, but seeing one nowadays is concerning to physicians at the University of Kansas Health System.  \"We haven't seen closures for a couple of years now, so I would imagine the leaders of this school had a good reason,\" said Dr. Dana Hawkinson, infectious disease specialist at the hospital. Dr. Hawkinson said COVID-19 cases have seen a small increase over the past few weeks, but as of now, the hospital isn't compiling any running totals of patients or cases. He is also reminding the public that other viruses that display cold-like symptoms are also spreading, as they often do when school groups begin fall classes. \"It's concerning that this early in the school year, we already have a closure,\" Dr. Hawkinson said Thursday. \"But we've all heard for the past few weeks either anecdotes of people who've been ill, or people in our community,  or just specific communities who are having increasing numbers of COVID as well. I think this is one good example of that.\" He said the public should consider reviving some forms of pandemic-era precautions, such as proper hand hygiene and avoiding unnecessary touching of the hands and eyes. On Thursday, FOX4 News reached out to both the Kansas Department of Health and Environment and the Wyandotte County Health Department, but neither provided any current COVID-related data for our coverage. The Archdiocese of Kansas City in Kansas sent us the following statement: \"Thank you for reaching out. The health and safety of our students and staff remain our highest priority, and our schools follow established safety and health protocols. At this time, I don't have additional information to share.\"","image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/fox4kc.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/sites\/16\/2025\/08\/Holy-Name-Catholic-School-KCK.jpg"},"articleSection":"News","genre":["Education","Health","Kansas News","News"],"keywords":["COVID","education","Family","health","Homepage","kansas city","Kansas City News","kansas news","KCK","outbreak"],"associatedMedia":[{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"COVID-19 outbreak forces Kansas City metro school to close","description":"Leaders at Holy Name of Jesus Catholic School in Kansas City, Kansas, confirmed that classes are canceled until Tuesday due to a COVID-19 outbreak at the school.","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/c104216-ucdn.mp.lura.live\/expiretime=2082787200\/b28408a4c7a2b7b83140816afc2fc3b59eeb478a1b47e455b238d6034caee038\/iupl_lin\/11F\/849\/11F849DF48D95CA0A8259FADF241A3F1_160x90.jpg","contentUrl":"https:\/\/tkx.mp.lura.live\/rest\/v2\/mcp\/video\/11026052.m3u8?anvack=70X35QbVjgovptmVD0HwZI0w9lNQk2R1&eud=8fNFXogAK%2FOkVuew899MLRHJxB7llXhAcuTfcxVu%2BJxbKjd29BjwA%2FaSbcseoHR%2FTyO8KsbFw40vgX8hrw%2Bxqw%3D%3D","uploadDate":"2025-08-28T18:43:22-05:00","duration":"P0DT0H2M36S"}]}</script>

	<div class="article-content article-body rich-text ">
		
		
<p>KANSAS CITY, Kan. â Students at a metro private school won’t be returning to class for a few days.</p>



<p>Leaders at Holy Name of Jesus Catholic School in Kansas City, Kansas, confirmed that classes are canceled until Tuesday due to a <a href="https://fox4kc.com/news/kck-school-shuts-down-for-the-week-after-covid-19-outbreak/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong>COVID-19 outbreak at the school</strong></a>. </p>


<div class="nlp-ignore-block article-content rich-text">
<aside class="promo-link">
	<a
		href="https://fox4kc.com/news/kck-school-shuts-down-for-the-week-after-covid-19-outbreak/?ipid=promo-link-block1"
		class="promo-link__link"
		target="_blank"	>
		KCK school shuts down for the week after COVID-19 outbreak	</a>
</aside>
</div>


<p>The school said on social media that classes are expected to resume after the Labor Day break. The post doesn’t specify whether students, faculty â or both â are affected by this spread.</p>
<div class="nexstar-minutemedia-player-container" hidden data-minutemedia-viewport="mobile" data-player-id="kvjhyvwn" data-stn-player="" data-s2n-api="minuteMediaS2NApi"></div>


<p>School closures were common during the pandemic, but seeing one nowadays is concerning to physicians at the University of Kansas Health System. </p>
<div class="nexstar-minutemedia-player-container" hidden data-minutemedia-viewport="desktop" data-player-id="kvjhyvwn" data-stn-player="" data-s2n-api="minuteMediaS2NApi"></div>


<p>“We haven’t seen closures for a couple of years now, so I would imagine the leaders of this school had a good reason,” said Dr. Dana Hawkinson, infectious disease specialist at the hospital.</p>



<p>Dr. Hawkinson said COVID-19 cases have seen a small increase over the past few weeks, but as of now, the hospital isn’t compiling any running totals of patients or cases. He is also reminding the public that other viruses that display cold-like symptoms are also spreading, as they often do when school groups begin fall classes.</p>

<aside class="ad-unit ad-unit--mr1_ab">
	<div class="ad-unit__content">
		     <div id="acm-ad-tag-mr1_ab-mr1_ab"         data-slot="{"is_oop":false,"is_companion":true,"sizes":[[[1280,0],[[300,250],[620,366]]],[[1024,0],[[300,250],[620,366]]],[[768,0],[[300,250],[325,204],[325,508]]],[[641,0],[[300,250],[325,204],[325,508]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[325,204],[325,508]]]],"size":[300,250]}"         data-unit="/5678/nx.wdaf/news"         data-fbonly="false"         data-refids=""         data-not-refids=""         data-targeting="{"kw":"covid-19-outbreak-forces-metro-school-to-close-until-next-week","pos":"mr1_ab","fold":"atf","category":"news"}"     ></div>     <script>     try {         var event = new CustomEvent("nsDfpSlotRendered", {             detail: { id: "acm-ad-tag-mr1_ab-mr1_ab" }         });         console.log("HTL.nsDfpSlotRendered", event);         window.dispatchEvent(event);     } catch (err) {}     </script>     	</div>
</aside>



<p>“It’s concerning that this early in the school year, we already have a closure,” Dr. Hawkinson said Thursday. </p>



<p>“But we’ve all heard for the past few weeks either anecdotes of people who’ve been ill, or people in our community,  or just specific communities who are having increasing numbers of COVID as well. I think this is one good example of that.”</p>



<p>He said the public should consider reviving some forms of pandemic-era precautions, such as proper hand hygiene and avoiding unnecessary touching of the hands and eyes.</p><div class="nlp-ignore-block article-content rich-text">
<aside class="promo-link">
	<a
		href="https://fox4kc.com/news/kansas-news/?ipid=wdaf_recirc_ks"
		class="promo-link__link"
		target="_blank"	>
		Kansas news: Headlines from Wichita, Topeka and around the Sunflower State	</a>
</aside>
</div></p>



<p>On Thursday, FOX4 News reached out to both the Kansas Department of Health and Environment and the Wyandotte County Health Department, but neither provided any current COVID-related data for our coverage.</p>

			function firstLoad() {
				if(getCookie('nxst-story-id')){
					origin = getCookie('nxst-story-id');
				}

				if ( nxsparam >= posts.length ) {
					return;
				}
				while ( ( posts[nxsparam]["id"] == current_id ) || ( posts[nxsparam]["id"] == origin ) ) {
					nxsparam++;
					if ( nxsparam >= posts.length ) {
						return;
					}
				}

				Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("nxslink")).forEach(function(elem) {
					nxsurl = posts[nxsparam]["url"] + "?nxsparam=" + (nxsparam+1);
					elem.setAttribute("href", nxsurl);
				});
				document.querySelectorAll('#btn-next').forEach(e => e.setAttribute('href', nxsurl))
				Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("nxstitle")).forEach(function(elem) {
					elem.innerHTML = posts[nxsparam]["title"];
				});
				if(posts[nxsparam]["image"]){
					Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("nxsimage")).forEach(function(elem) {
						elem.setAttribute("src", posts[nxsparam]["image"]);
					});
				} else {
					Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("col-image")).forEach(function(elem) {
						elem.style.display = "none";
					});
				}

				if(getCookie('nxstoryVariation') == 'nxstory-auto-minimalist'){
					variantValue = getCookie('nxstoryVariation');
				} else{
					variantValue = 'nxstory-auto-minimalist';
				}

				card = cards.find(elem => elem['layout'] == 'minimalist' && elem['autoturn'] == 1);
				variant = 4;

				if(card['datasource'] == ''){
					return;
				}

				setCookie('nxstoryVariation', variantValue, 30 * 24);

				counter = card['timer'];
				Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("btn-counter")).forEach(function(elem) {
					elem.innerHTML = counter;
				});

				Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName('btn-read-next')).forEach(function(elem) {
					elem.innerHTML = card['title'];
				});
				Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName('btn-next-text')).forEach(function(elem) {
					elem.innerHTML = card['linktext'];
				});
			}

			function initCounter(){
				if(variant == 0 || card == undefined){
					return;
				}

				let auxvariant = variant-1;
				if(document.getElementsByClassName('nxstory')[auxvariant]){
					const nxstoryViewEvent = new CustomEvent(
						'nxstoryView',
						{
							detail: {
								target: document.getElementsByClassName('nxstory')[auxvariant],
							}
						},
					);

					document.getElementsByClassName('nxstory')[auxvariant].style.bottom = '100px';
					dispatchEvent(nxstoryViewEvent);
				}

				if(auxvariant == 2 || auxvariant == 3){
					Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("btn-progress")).forEach(function(elem) {
						elem.style.setProperty('-webkit-animation', 'progressBar '+counter+'s linear');
					});
					Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("btn-progress")).forEach(function(elem) {
						elem.style.setProperty('-moz-animation', 'progressBar '+counter+'s linear');
					});
					Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("btn-progress")).forEach(function(elem) {
						elem.style.setProperty('-webkit-animation-fill-mode', 'both');
					});
					Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("btn-progress")).forEach(function(elem) {
						elem.style.setProperty('-moz-animation-fill-mode', 'both');
					});

					myCounter = setInterval(function () {
						if(counter > 0){
							counter--;
							Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName("btn-counter")).forEach(function(elem) {
								elem.innerHTML = counter;
							});
							if(counter < 1){
								redirect(nxsurl);
								clearInterval(myCounter);
							}
						}
					}, 1000);
				}
			}

			function dismissNxsStory(){
				clearInterval(myCounter);
				Array.from(document.getElementsByClassName('nxstory')).forEach(function(elem) {
					elem.style.bottom='-100%';
					elem.style.display='none';
				});
				return false;
			}

			function redirect(url) {
				clicked = false;
				clicktype = '';
				function addParam(url, name) {
					newurl = new URL(url);
					newurl.searchParams.append(name, 1);
					return newurl.toString()
				}
				if(event){
					event.preventDefault();
				}
				if (getCookie('nxst-story-id') === "") {
					setCookie('nxst-story-id', current_id);
				}
				if(!url){
					if(event){
						clicked = true;
						nxstorycontainer = event.target.closest('[class*=nxstory-]');
						variant = nxstorycontainer.dataset.variant;
						if (variant.includes('auto')) {
							clicktype = 'auto'
						}
						url = event.target.closest("a").getAttribute('href');
					}
				}
				if (clicked) {
					if (clicktype === 'auto'){
						url = addParam(url, 'nxstory_autoturn_click')
					} else {
						url = addParam(url, 'nxstory_click')
					}
				} else {
					url = addParam(url, 'nxstory_autoturn')
				}
				window.location.href = url;
				return false;
			}

readabilityObject.title: COVID-19 outbreak forces metro school to close until next week
readabilityObject.content:
KANSAS CITY, Kan. â Students at a metro private school wonât be returning to class for a few days.

Leaders at Holy Name of Jesus Catholic School in Kansas City, Kansas, confirmed that classes are canceled until Tuesday due to a COVID-19 outbreak at the school.

The school said on social media that classes are expected to resume after the Labor Day break. The post doesnât specify whether students, faculty â or both â are affected by this spread.

School closures were common during the pandemic, but seeing one nowadays is concerning to physicians at the University of Kansas Health System. 

âWe havenât seen closures for a couple of years now, so I would imagine the leaders of this school had a good reason,â said Dr. Dana Hawkinson, infectious disease specialist at the hospital.

Dr. Hawkinson said COVID-19 cases have seen a small increase over the past few weeks, but as of now, the hospital isnât compiling any running totals of patients or cases. He is also reminding the public that other viruses that display cold-like symptoms are also spreading, as they often do when school groups begin fall classes.

âItâs concerning that this early in the school year, we already have a closure,â Dr. Hawkinson said Thursday.

âBut weâve all heard for the past few weeks either anecdotes of people whoâve been ill, or people in our community,  or just specific communities who are having increasing numbers of COVID as well. I think this is one good example of that.â

He said the public should consider reviving some forms of pandemic-era precautions, such as proper hand hygiene and avoiding unnecessary touching of the hands and eyes.

On Thursday, FOX4 News reached out to both the Kansas Department of Health and Environment and the Wyandotte County Health Department, but neither provided any current COVID-related data for our coverage.

The Archdiocese of Kansas City in Kansas sent us the following statement:

âThank you for reaching out. The health and safety of our students and staff remain our highest priority, and our schools follow established safety and health protocols. At this time, I donât have additional information to share.â

readabilityObject.textContent:
KANSAS CITY, Kan. â Students at a metro private school wonât be returning to class for a few days.



Leaders at Holy Name of Jesus Catholic School in Kansas City, Kansas, confirmed that classes are canceled until Tuesday due to a COVID-19 outbreak at the school. 





The school said on social media that classes are expected to resume after the Labor Day break. The post doesnât specify whether students, faculty â or both â are affected by this spread.



School closures were common during the pandemic, but seeing one nowadays is concerning to physicians at the University of Kansas Health System.Â 



âWe havenât seen closures for a couple of years now, so I would imagine the leaders of this school had a good reason,â said Dr. Dana Hawkinson, infectious disease specialist at the hospital.



Dr. Hawkinson said COVID-19 cases have seen a small increase over the past few weeks, but as of now, the hospital isnât compiling any running totals of patients or cases. He is also reminding the public that other viruses that display cold-like symptoms are also spreading, as they often do when school groups begin fall classes.





âItâs concerning that this early in the school year, we already have a closure,â Dr. Hawkinson said Thursday. 



âBut weâve all heard for the past few weeks either anecdotes of people whoâve been ill, or people in our community,Â  or just specific communities who are having increasing numbers of COVID as well. I think this is one good example of that.â



He said the public should consider reviving some forms of pandemic-era precautions, such as proper hand hygiene and avoiding unnecessary touching of the hands and eyes.



On Thursday, FOX4 News reached out to both the Kansas Department of Health and Environment and the Wyandotte County Health Department, but neither provided any current COVID-related data for our coverage.





The Archdiocese of Kansas City in Kansas sent us the following statement:



âThank you for reaching out. The health and safety of our students and staff remain our highest priority, and our schools follow established safety and health protocols. At this time, I donât have additional information to share.â
